<title level="1" right="Rules">[A Garden by Any Other Name](/Rules.aspx?ID=1935)</title>

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Treasure Vault](/Sources.aspx?ID=191) pg. 168 <sup>1.1</sup></row>

<row gap="medium">
<column gap="medium" flex="1 1 400px">
While a garden is especially narratively attractive to characters like [herbalists](/Archetypes.aspx?ID=62), [druids](/Classes.aspx?ID=6), [poisoners](/Archetypes.aspx?ID=71), [leshys](/Ancestries.aspx?ID=14), and the like, these same guidelines are perfectly capable of describing locations far different than a natural location lush with plant life. Here are a few examples.
</column>

<column gap="medium">

</column>

</row>

<document level="2" id="rules-1936" />

<document level="2" id="rules-1937" />

<document level="2" id="rules-1938" />

<document level="2" id="rules-1939" />

<document level="2" id="rules-1940" />
name: A Garden by Any Other Name

text: A Garden by Any Other Name Source Treasure Vault pg. 168 1.1 While a garden is especially narratively attractive to characters like herbalists, druids, poisoners, leshys, and the like, these same guidelines are perfectly capable of describing locations far different than a natural location lush with plant life. Here are a few examples.
